subject: Re: [junit] Testing multiple interfaces?
msgSnippet: ... * snip * ... This implies that the TestRunner doesn t use suite() to find tests in each class file, right? I didn t know that--I have a suite() defined for
messageBody:
J. B. Rainsberger wrote:
> jason r tibbetts wrote:
>
* snip *
>>I want to write something like the following, but I'm looking for better
>>ideas:
>>
>>public class FooBar implements Foo, Bar { ... }
>>
>>public class BarTestBase extends TestCase {
>> protected Bar bar;
>>
>> public void testSomeMethod() { ... }
>>}
>>
>>// does NOT subclass FooTestBase or BarTestBase
>>public class FooBarTest extends TestCase {
>> static class FooSubclassTest extends FooTestBase {
>> protected void setUp() { foo = new FooBar(); }
>> }
>>
>> static class BarSubclassTest extends BarTestBase {
>> protected void setUp() { foo = new FooBar(); }
>> }
>>
>> public static Test suite() {
>> TestSuite suite = new TestSuite(FooBarTest.class);
>> suite.addTest(new TestSuite(FooSubclassTest.class); // ?
>> suite.addTest(new TestSuite(BarSubclassTest.class); // ?
>> return suite;
>> }
>>}
>
>
> You've done here what I would do, except you've added a suite() method
> to collect all the "FooBar" tests together. Since I usually try to run
> all my tests all the time, I'd get that free.

This implies that the TestRunner doesn't use suite() to find tests in
each class file, right? I didn't know that--I have a suite() defined for
all of my concrete test classes. Besides, I still use the crummy
junit.swingui.TestRunner on occassion, and that uses suite().

>>Considerations:
>>* This keeps all of the tests for the FooBar class in a single file.
>
> I don't find this important, but that's personal taste.

I agree that this isn't terribly important, but it depends on your
development setup. I want a quick way to find which tests cover which
CUTs, so I've created a custom Javadoc taglet ("@...") for class
comments so that they'll generate a link to the appropriate test case
documentation.

>>* Because the static inner test classes' names end with 'Test', they'll
>>be picked up automatically by an Ant <junit> task that executes anything
>>called '*Test.class', right? If so, then adding them to the FooBarTest's
>>suite is redundant.
>
> That's handy.
>
>>* If the inner classes' names end in 'Test', they must be declared
>>static in order to prevent a reflection exception when the JUnit test
>>loader attempts to invoke them, since they'd have to be instantiated
>>within an instance of FooBarTest.
>
>
> That makes sense.
>
> I think you're on the right track here. Let us know how it works for
> you. This is one of those deeper examples that no-one has written about
> in detail yet. (Even _JUnit Recipes_ only mentions it in passing.) You
> should write about your experiences with this pattern and share it with
> the world. :)

Will do. Thanks for your input.
